channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: News Analysis: Baghdad Attacks by ISIS Point to Trouble for Group, but Not Imminent Defeat
item.media:description: Sadr City, a teeming Shiite district in northeastern Baghdad, was one of the four areas hit by suicide bombing attacks on Tuesday that killed 80 people.
item.description: There is truth to the idea that the terrorists have resorted to lashing out in Baghdad because they are abandoning territory to pro-Iraqi ground forces and airstrikes. But this is not the group’s final death throes — not yet.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Senate Passes Bill Exposing Saudi Arabia to 9/11 Legal Claims
item.media:description: President Obama with Adel al-Jubeir, the Saudi foreign minister, during a trip to the kingdom last month.
item.description: The legislation, now headed to the House and opposed by the White House, is another sign of escalating tensions between the Mideast nation and the U.S.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: From Dog Farms in South Korea to New Lives as Pets Abroad
item.media:description: A dog was rescued last month from a farm in Wonju, South Korea. Humane Society International offers to pay farmers to release dogs so they can be sent abroad to be adopted.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: An animal-rights group has had success offering dog farmers thousands of dollars to give up their animals to be adopted as pets abroad.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte’s Talk of Killing Criminals Raises Fears in Philippines
item.media:description: Clarita Alia with photos of her four sons, who were killed in Davao City, the Philippines. They were said to have been summarily executed by armed men after being accused of petty crimes and drug use in their slum.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Duterte boasted of killing criminals when he was mayor of Davao, and investigators say they have evidence of government-linked death squads.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Obama to Relax U.S. Sanctions Against Myanmar
item.media:description: President Obama with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi at her home in Yangon, Myanmar, in 2014, when she headed the opposition. She led the party that won national elections and was elevated to the state counselor, the leader of Myanmar, formerly known as Burma.
item.description: The moves, which go into effect Wednesday, will allow American individuals, banks and companies to do business with all Burmese financial institutions.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: In Syria Talks, U.S. and Russia Propose Airdrops if Assad Forces Block Aid
item.description: The pledge of airdrops by Secretary of State John Kerry and his Russian counterpart, Sergey V. Lavrov, amounted to an admission of how little progress has been made on a lasting cease-fire or regular humanitarian relief.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: I.M.F. Takes Firmer Stand Favoring Relief for Greek Debt
item.media:description: Riot police in Athens. Thousands of people marched across Greece in February to protest changes in pensions. The I.M.F. is adamant that Greece will never return to growth if its debt burden is not sustainable.
item.description: The fund’s position is counter to Germany’s on the wisdom and future of austerity commitments, potentially setting up a conflict with creditors.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Fort McMurray Wildfire Upends Plan to Restart Oil Sands Operations
item.description: Just as the Canadian oil sands companies were preparing to resume full-scale operations, they and residents of the area were forced to stay away.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Mexican President Moves to Legalize Gay Marriage Nationwide
item.description: President Enrique Peña Nieto submitted a proposal to Congress that would bring legislation into line with recent Supreme Court rulings.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN and AZAM AHMED
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Young and Oppose ‘Brexit’? You May Be David Cameron’s Match on Tinder
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain spoke on Tuesday in London about the country’s referendum on leaving the European Union.
item.description: Britain’s prime minister is exploring advertising on the dating app and other social media to get young people, who polls suggest want to stay in the European Union, to vote.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Smugglers Made at Least $5 Billion Last Year in Europe Migrant Crisis
item.description: A report by multinational law enforcement agencies said 90 percent of the migrants reaching the European Union were helped by smugglers.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Canada Moves to Ban Discrimination Against Transgender People
item.media:description: Supporters of transgender rights listening to a news conference on Tuesday in Ottawa announcing that Canada would introduce legislation to protect transgender people from discrimination and hate crimes.
item.description: New legislation would classify victimizing people because of their gender identity or gender expression as a hate crime.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Taj Mahal Under Attack by Bugs and Their Green Slime
item.media:description: The Taj Mahal, shown in April, sits by the Yamuna River in Agra, India. The effects of pollution on India’s cultural heritage sites, though less obvious than their impact on health, are worthy of attention, experts say.
item.description: Mosquito-like insects are discoloring the Taj Mahal, mainly because the badly polluted Yamuna River nearby provides an environment where they thrive.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR and SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: Letter from Europe: Britain’s Youth Versus ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: Marvin Rees, the 43-year-old mayor of Bristol, England, is said to be “the first directly elected city mayor in Europe of African or Caribbean heritage.”
item.description: Young Britons seem to favor staying in the bloc. They have never known a divided Europe without visa-free travel, cheap flights and job mobility.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: On Visit to Hong Kong, Beijing Official Draws Protest
item.media:description: A protest against Mr. Zhang in Hong Kong on Tuesday. Mr. Zhang oversaw efforts in 2003 to play down an outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, in Guangdong Province. It spread to neighboring Hong Kong.
item.description: Zhang Dejiang, a member of the Politburo Standing Committee, is remembered by many for attempting to cover up the 2003 SARS outbreak.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG

item.title: Thailand Will Close a Popular Island to Tourists
item.media:description: Koh Tachai, Thailand. The Department of National Parks, Wildlife and Plant Conservation is closing the beaches, the reef and a tourist area on the island “to solve the environmental and natural resources impact which is caused by tourism.”
item.media:credit: Caine Delacy for The New York Times
item.description: The government says the action is necessary because Koh Tachai, famous for its white beaches and coral reefs, has deteriorated from abuse by hordes of visitors.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Kilinochchi Journal: Rebuilding Lives, and Homes, Shattered by Sri Lanka’s Civil War
item.media:description: The Ramasamys at their home in Kilinochchi, Sri Lanka.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Survivors of Sri Lanka’s 26-year conflict have slowly returned to the Kilinochchi area, after months or even years in government rehabilitation camps.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND and DHARISHA BASTIANS

item.title: Top E.U. Official Calls Boris Johnson’s Remarks on E.U. and Hitler ‘Absurd’
item.media:description: The president of the European Council, Donald Tusk, left, at a news conference in Copenhagen on Tuesday, where he criticized the former mayor of London, Boris Johnson.
item.description: Donald Tusk said the former London mayor had “political amnesia” when he equated the European Union with the German dictator.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Asia: North Korea Is Said to Appoint Career Envoy as Foreign Minister
item.media:description: Ri Yong-ho, left, in Singapore in 2015. He was North Korea’s senior nuclear negotiator at the time.
item.description: North Korea has promoted Ri Yong-ho, a diplomat, to succeed Foreign Minister Ri Su-yong, a South Korean government official said.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Australia to Lay Off Leading Scientist on Sea Levels
item.media:description: Ice off the western Antarctic Peninsula in March. Australia’s science agency is laying off 275 scientists as it shifts its focus away from climate research and toward more commercial projects.
item.description: The climate expert, John Church, confirmed that he was one of 275 scientists that an Australian science agency said would be dismissed.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.category: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (Australia)

item.title: Much of World Suffers Not From Abuse of Painkillers, but Absence of Them
item.media:description: An H.I.V. patient cooling off at a treatment center on the outskirts of Yangon, Myanmar, in 2012. The use of opioid analgesics to relieve pain is low in Asia and much of the developing world.
item.description: While the United States struggles with a surge in addiction, an estimated 5.5 billion people live in countries with little or no access to opioid analgesics.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere: Excerpt From People’s Daily on the Cultural Revolution
item.media:description: Soldiers writing messages of support for Mao Zedong and the Communist Party on a blackboard in Beijing in June 1966.
item.description: The Communist Party newspaper said the lessons of the Cultural Revolution can help Chinese society advance.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: What in the World: In Finland, a Postal Worker Will Mow Your Lawn
item.media:description: Neither snow nor rain nor heat nor untidy grass will stop Finnish couriers.
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; Photos by Charles Brutlag, Mega Pixel, Claudio Divizia/Shutterstock
item.description: Stamp sales have slumped in the digital era, so postal services are trying new ways to earn revenue — some of them far afield from carrying the mail.
item.dc:creator: JAKE DOHERTY

item.title: What in the World: The Mountain That Tops Everest (Because the Earth Is Fat)
item.media:description: Earth flattens at its poles and bulges slightly around its waistline, making its radius about 13 miles greater at the Equator.
item.description: Mount Chimborazo in Ecuador rises about 20,500 feet above sea level, far short of Everest’s 29,029 feet. But it’s a different story when you measure from the center of the Earth.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: What in the World: Japan Has a Kit Kat for Every Taste, and Then Some
item.media:credit: Illustration by Craig Allen; Photos by Nestlé Japan
item.description: There are nearly 300 varieties of Kit Kat in Japan, where the candy is so popular that it is sold at high-end department stores, Kit Kat-only shops and even post offices.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Cossacks Clash Violently With Kremlin Opposition Leader and Supporters
item.description: Aleksei A. Navalny and his associates were returning to Moscow from a hiking trip in southern Russia when a group of men threw bags of milk at them, prompting a melee that was captured on video.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How I Survived Four and a Half Years in Captivity
item.description: My Islamist kidnappers tried to break my spirit. But even in the mountains of Afghanistan I found strength.
item.dc:creator: SHAHBAZ TASEER

item.title: Editorial: Block the Sale of Warplanes to Nigeria
item.media:description: President Muhammadu Buhari of Nigeria
item.description: Although the government is fighting Boko Haram, its security services have a tainted record, with extrajudicial killings, torture and rape.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Know-Nothing Tide
item.description: Trump says America was strongest when “politics ended at water's edge.” He's wrong.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: On the Ground in Aleppo: Bloodshed, Misery and Hope
item.media:description: A civilian evacuated a baby on Friday from a site that had been hit by airstrikes in a rebel-controlled area of Aleppo, Syria. Inhabitants of the city carry on with work and school despite fighting that has killed more than 200 civilians in the past week.
item.description: The New York Times’s Cairo bureau chief reported from Aleppo, Syria, where inhabitants try to carry on despite a civil war’s inescapable reality.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
